div.p: Greetings. A young man unknown to me, but very familiar to Mr. Carlinus due to his parent, is coming to you.
He trusts that in the name of Carlinus, myself, and his deceased parent, his studies will be taken care of by you.
Therefore, for your humanity, do what you can and what we trust you will do.
Willingus, the court preacher of the Palatinate, would have also written to you; but when the young man left, he was absent.
Do as much as you can.
The Lord, who is accustomed to visit us in many ways, will repay.
Our school seemed not at all suitable for him and therefore not to be visited; if he is received by you, perhaps you will educate such a one who will someday be useful to the Church of Christ.
I have no news, except that there is a rumor that the Margrave of Brandenburg is assembling an army; however, it is not known for what reason; but I affirm nothing certain.
I wish I could have your response sent to the Palatinate; I would return it in good faith and immediately, as well as the action of Strasbourg, which will be sent to you from Basel.
Furthermore (but I write this only to you) it is secretly indicated to me that all the Swiss Cantons, indeed all the Swiss, think very poorly of the people of Schaffhausen.
I heard three reasons: the action of Stierli, also of Tarer, hence of Molitor; two more remain, which he could not recite to me.

Therefore, several thousand florins have been forced upon the people of Schaffhausen, as no justice prevails among us; they wish to erase the ancient praise of the Swiss from our people; or they return the letters of the Swiss Confederation.
If these things are true, surely you have understood from the consul; therefore, I ask you to inform me; there is no reason to fear no danger here.
However, I wish to know for certain reasons.
Farewell in the Lord, who may keep you safe for us for a long time. Have our church commended to you and greet all our supporters.
Most devoted to your humanity, Jakob RÃ¼eger.
To the most illustrious and learned man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, first and most vigilant Antistes of the Church of Zurich, his most esteemed lord and brother.
